721774f-a.title: Manhattan: Mott Street - Houston Street
721774f-a.text:
Mott Street, west side, north from Houston, to, but not including
Bleecker Streets, as seen through clearance on Houston Street, for the
Eighth Ave., Subway.
September 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS2
721774f-a.folder: Mott Street & Houston Street, Manhattan, NY

719461f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Mott Street
719461f-a.text:
(1)
East Houston Street, south side, west from (No. 47) but not
including Mott, to Lafayette Streets, showing prominently the Puck
Building (from Mulberry to Lafayette Streets). It is a handsome
edifice in the Italian Renaissance stvle, and is occupied by the
J. Ottman Lithographing Co., the foremost establishment of its kind
on the American continent, and the magazine'Puck, a publication
satirising the political and social life of our country. The building
was erected sometime between the second and third quarters of the 19th
century and is 9-stories tall.
June 3, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A detail of the Puck Building (the S.W. corner of East Houston
and Mulberry Streets) at an earlier date, showing the pretty,
emblematic figure of Puck, standing on a long, graceful column, with
a crayon as a staff in one hand and a mirror in the other.
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
719461f-a.folder: Houston Street (East) & Mott Street, Manhattan, NY

719465f-a.title: Manhattan: Houston Street (East) - Mott Street
719465f-a.text:
(1)
64 East Houston Street, north side, between Nott and Elizabeth
Streets, showing the entrance to a 1-story frame house, situated at the
rear of No. 66 (part of which is seen on the extreme right), and is1
occupied by a smithy. The blcl of houses of which these are a part
were later razed to make way forLthe construction of the Independent
System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway).
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A view from the same point of vantage at a later date and after demolition.
T8e three 6-story tenements shown on the right are Nos. 291 to 295
Elinabeth Street. The cleared area is a playground today (1937).
March 12, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
